title-group.article-title: Evaluation of the Energy Efficiencies of Pre-cast Composite Columns

contrib-group.aff: Department of Architectural Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin 446-701, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Seon-Chee Park, Department of Architectural Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin, 446-701, Korea. Tel. +82-31-201-3733, Fax. +82-31-204-5686, E-Mail pscgogo@khu.ac.kr

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on: Sustainable Development for Future Building

permissions.copyright-holder: International Society of the Built Environment

abstract.p: Columns manufactured with pre-cast concrete could reduce construction waste and CO2 emissions by reducing the use of temporary materials such as formwork. In this paper, three types of connection methods are introduced. The structural performance of pre-cast composite columns connected to beams was investigated for the column connection. Multi-story pre-cast composite columns could significantly reduce the construction time, resulting in a decrease in CO2 emissions. This paper reports the analysis of the compression and bending of a two-story column so as to verify the structural performances of pre-cast composite columns to provide adequate integrity to ensure a safe environment for building accommodation. In addition, a steel-framed column and a steel-framed reinforced concrete (SRC) column configured to feature the same compression performance as a pre-cast composite column were designed on the basis of the analysis results. The CO2 emissions and energy efficiency of the composite columns were compared with those of conventional steel and SRC columns during the design and construction phases. This paper also presents new composite columns providing efficient energy consumption with reduced CO2 emissions for a more environmentally conscientious construction of buildings.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Environmental pollution has emerged as a major issue worldwide. Various industries devote much time and effort to reducing energy consumption and CO2 emissions. The construction industry is no exception to such a trend, and researchers are studying new construction methods and structural members as buildings are becoming taller and larger. W.K. Hong developed steel-framed reinforced concrete composite beams that can be used in apartment buildings, the structural performance of which have been demonstrated [1–3]. Steel-framed reinforced concrete composite structures have already been shown to be more environmentally friendly than bearing wall structures or flat slab structures since they are more energy-efficient and are associated with reduced CO2 emissions [4–7].

Connecting the steel frame of a composite beam to ordinary reinforced concrete (RC) or steel columns has been a problem. To address this issue, this paper has proposed a pre-cast composite column that may be easily connected to a composite beam. A pre-cast composite column, a steel column, and a steel-framed reinforced concrete (SRC) column with similar nominal axial strengths were compared in terms of energy consumption and CO2 emissions so as to investigate the environmental advantages of pre-cast composite columns.

sec.title: Concept of Pre-cast Composite Columns
sec.p: The pre-cast composite column proposed in this paper was developed for efficient connection between a column and a composite beam. It is difficult to connect steel-framed reinforced concrete composite beams and RC columns. Such difficulties result in structural problems during construction. To resolve this issue, structural steel with a length equal to the depth of the beam was embedded in column for connection to composite beams. In such a case, it is possible to connect the steel frame of the composite beam to the embedded structural steel in the same manner as is used in a conventional steel frame connection. Since the upper reinforcing steel placed along the length of the beam is installed through the steel frame in the connection, constructability is improved and the structural safety of the connection is ensured. In addition, pre-cast composite columns of up to three stories in height can be fabricated in a factory. Thus, the construction schedule can be shortened and the use of temporary construction materials such as formwork can be minimized. Also, pre-cast composite columns can reduce energy consumption and CO2 emissions.

sec.title: Connection Method
sec.p: As in a two-story composite column connection, a sleeve, a coupler, and pressure-welding were employed in this work.

Sleeve joints require installation of a sleeve in the main reinforcement of the upper composite column. The main reinforcement of the lower composite column is inserted into the sleeve, which is then filled with high-strength non-shrinkage mortar. The base plate of the upper steel frame in the column joint was designed to match the cross-section of the column so that the column reinforcement could penetrate the base plate. Consequently, the base plate was intended to serve as the shear connection member to connect the upper and lower columns. The sleeve joint between columns is shown in Figure 1. Fig. 1.
Sleeve joint method.

A coupler joint requires a coupler to connect the upper main reinforcement and the lower main reinforcement in the column-to-column connection joint. Couplers are placed at different vertical locations to avoid the damage of the structural performance of the connection. These different locations of couplers allow the horizontal reinforcing steels to pass without interference. In addition, couplers were placed at a lower position to adjust for the construction error. In the same manner as was used for the sleeve joint, the coupler joint requires the top base plate of the column connection to match the size of the column cross-section which, then, results column reinforcement both to penetrate the base plate and to be connected by the coupler. In other words, exposed reinforced steel in the pre-cast composite column is installed to penetrate the base plate of the column connection steel frame attached to the lower column. The column-to-column coupler joint is shown in Figure 2. Fig. 2.
Coupler joint method.

Pressure-welding requires the main reinforcements of the upper and lower composite columns to be pressure-welded. Since pressure-welding does not result in a mechanical connection, it is difficult to ensure uniform quality across different connections, requiring that thorough quality control and connection strength checks than sleeve joints or coupler joints are necessary for pressure-welding. A column-to-column connection using pressure-welding is shown in Figure 3. Fig. 3.
Pressure-welding method.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p: To understand the structural performances of column-to-column connections, a two-story column was analyzed. A horizontal load was first applied to the connection of the two-story column, the ends of which were fixed. The maximum horizontal load was then estimated. A free-body diagram that shows the application of a horizontal load to a two-story column is shown in Figure 4. The diagram indicates an outcome similar to that for a beam in which a concentrated load is applied to the centre can be expected.

A cross-section of the composite column used in the analysis is shown in Figure 5. The compressive strength of the concrete used in the composite column was 35 MPa. The steel frame to be used in this analysis for the connection was composed of SM490 steel and the reinforcement steels with the yield strength of 400 MPa. The cross-sectional size of the column was 600 mm × 600 mm, similar to those found in construction sites. A total of 12 reinforcement steels with a diameter of 25 mm was used for the cross-section, and the steel frame had dimensions of 250 mm × 250 mm × 9 mm × 14 mm as seen in Figure 5. Fig. 4.
Free-body diagram of a two-story column. Fig. 5.
A cross section of composite column.

To calculate the nominal moment of the composite column, the strength design method was used. In the strength design method analysis, the following assumptions are employed:
The strains of the reinforcement and concrete are proportional to the distance from the neutral axis.
The strain of the concrete at the edge of the compressive side is limited to be 0.003.
The stress of the reinforcement at or below the yield strength fy is Es times greater than the strain. If the strain is larger than the value corresponding to the yield strength fy, the stress of the reinforcement is assumed to be the same as fy irrespective of the strain.
The tensile strength of the concrete is ignored in the bending stress calculation.
At ultimate strength, the stress of the concrete is not proportional to the strain. The distribution of the bending compression stress of the concrete can be assumed to be rectangular, trapezoidal, parabolic, or any shape that effectively corresponds to extensive experimental outcomes in strength prediction [8].

The nominal moment was calculated to be 563.72 kN. On the assumption that the calculated nominal moment is the same as the maximum moment of the column shown in Figure 4, the maximum concentrated load applied horizontally to the column-to-column connection was calculated to be 683.3 kN.

sec.title: Functional Unit of Energy Consumption
sec.p:
Various types of energy sources were used to produce important key materials for construction. The original unit of energy consumption was calculated by estimating the energy consumed per unit output with the assumption that energy used in the production process was included in the end product. The energy consumption per original unit of raw materials was estimated with the indirect estimation method using an inter-industry analysis table from 2009 [9]. The energy consumption per unit estimated according to the inter-industry analysis was found to be almost identical to that found with the direct calculation method. The energy consumption per original unit obtained via inter-industry analysis is believed to be highly reliable. Table 1 shows the energy consumptions of key materials per original unit. Table 1.
Energy consumption per original unit for major construction materials [9]
Architectural component Original unit Energy consumption per original unit (MJ/Original unit)
Ready-mixed concrete m3 2,406.393
Reinforcing steel kN 3,522.222
Steel section kN 4,065.782
Formwork m2 240.672

sec.title: Analysis of CO2 Emission by Material
sec.p:
The CO2 emissions data per original unit of key material are given in Table 2. These data were based on ‘‘The Environmental Load Unit Composition and Program Development for LCA of Building’’ and the second annual report of the Construction Technology R&D Program, Korea Institute of Construction & Transportation Technology Evaluation and Planning [10]. The production of major construction materials for cement, ready-mix concrete, concrete products, and reinforcing steel accounts for approximately 58% of the total CO2 emissions. Table 2.
CO2 emissions per original unit for major construction materials [10]
Architectural component CO2 emission per original unit
Ready-mix concrete 140.43 kg-CO2/m3
High strength reinforcing steel 407.96 kg-CO2/kN
Steel section 377.10 kg-CO2/kN
Formwork 3.83 kg-CO2/m2

sec.title: Comparison of Energy Consumptions & CO2 Emissions
sec.p:
Steel and SRC columns with cross-sections corresponding to a nominal axis load of 11457 kN were selected to compare energy consumptions and CO2 emissions. The member size of the steel column was selected to be 416 mm × 405 mm × 9 mm × 14 mm as seen in Figure 6(a). The cross-section of the SRC column was 500 mm ×500 mm and the total of 12 reinforcement steels with a diameter of 25 mm were used, and the 250 mm ×250 mm × 9 mm × 14 mm structural steel was used as seen in Figure 6(b). Fig. 6.
Cross-sections of the columns.

The amounts of concrete, reinforcing steel, steel frame, and formwork used in the pre-cast composite column, steel column, and SRC column are shown in Table 3. It can be seen that the same amount of reinforcing steel is used in the pre-cast composite column and the SRC column. Since the steel column consists of only a single member, only the steel frame quantity was calculated. The quantities of formwork used in the pre-cast composite column and SRC column were estimated at the construction site. Table 3.
Quantities of construction materials used in the columns
Pre-cast composite column Steel column SRC column
Concrete (m3) 1.06 – 0.70
Reinforcing steel (kN) 1.40 – 1.40
Steel frame (kN) 0.32 7.38 2.13
Formwork (m2) 0.54 – 3.00
The total energy consumption and CO2 emissions of each column were calculated according to the quantity of each material and by applying the original units of energy consumption and CO2 emissions.

The energy consumptions of the concrete used in the SRC column and the pre-cast composite column were estimated to be 1694.35 MJ and 2545.03 MJ, respectively. The CO2 emissions of the concrete used in the SRC column and the pre-cast composite column were estimated to be 98.88 kg-CO2 and 148.52 kg-CO2, respectively.

The same amount of reinforcing steel was used in the pre-cast composite column and the SRC column. As such, the energy consumptions and CO2 emissions of the reinforcing steel in each of the two columns are equal. The energy consumption of the reinforcing steel was found to be 4946.21 MJ, while the CO2 emission from the reinforcing steel was 572.89 kg-CO2.

The energy consumption and CO2 emissions of the steel frame used in the pre-cast composite column were estimated to be 1299.02 MJ and 120.48 kg-CO2, respectively. The energy consumption and CO2 emissions of the steel column were estimated to be 29995.31 MJ and 3009.72 kg-CO2, respectively.

The energy consumptions resulting from the formwork used in the pre-cast composite column and the SRC column were estimated to be 129.96 MJ and 722.02 MJ, respectively, while the CO2 emissions resulting from the formwork of the pre-cast composite and SRC columns were 2.07 kg-CO2 and 11.49 kg-CO2, respectively.

The energy consumptions and CO2 emissions corresponding to the quantities of concrete, reinforcing steel, formwork, and steel frame in each column type are shown in Table 4. Table 4.
Energy consumptions and CO2 emissions for each material
Energy Consumption (MJ) CO2 Emissions (kg-CO2)
Pre-cast composite column Steel column SRC column Pre-cast composite column Steel column SRC column
Concrete 2545.03 – 1694.35 148.52 – 98.88
Reinforcing steel 4946.21 – 4946.21 572.89 – 572.89
Steel frame 1299.02 29995.31 8660.12 120.48 3009.72 803.22
Formwork 129.96 – 722.02 2.07 – 11.49
Total 8920.22 29995.31 16022.70 843.96 3009.72 1486.48

The energy consumptions and CO2 emissions from the materials used in each column are shown in Figure 7. The energy consumption and CO2 emissions according to concrete were greater in the composite column than in the SRC column. This is attributable to the steel frame embedded in the SRC column. However, formwork is used throughout the SRC column fabrication process, while the pre-cast composite column uses formwork only for the connection region. The aggregate energy consumption and CO2 emissions of the formwork used in SRC column fabrication are three and four times greater, respectively, than those of the composite column. Because the steel frame is composed of a single material, only the energy consumption and CO2 emissions for the steel frame were calculated. Since the basic units of energy consumption and CO2 emissions of the steel frame were significantly larger than those in the other members, the energy consumption and CO2 emission for the steel column were also significantly greater than those in the other columns. Fig. 7.
Energy consumptions and CO2 emissions from the materials used in each column.

The total CO2 emissions and energy consumption of each column are shown in Figures 8 and 9, respectively. The total energy consumption was calculated to be 8920.22 MJ, 29995.31 MJ and 16022.7 MJ for the pre-cast composite column, steel column, and SRC column, respectively. The energy consumption of the pre-cast composite column amounted to 29.74% and 55.67% of the energy consumption of the steel and SRC columns, respectively. The CO2 emissions of the pre-cast composite column, steel column, and SRC column were calculated to be 843.96 kg-CO2, 3009.72 kg-CO2, and 1486.48 kg-CO2, respectively. The CO2 emissions of the pre-cast composite column amounted to 28.04% and 56.78% of that of the steel and SRC columns, respectively. Fig. 8.
Energy consumptions for key materials. Fig. 9.
CO2 emissions for key materials.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
An analysis of the connection of a pre-cast composite column was performed. The pre-cast composite column was also compared with other columns with a similar axial load in terms of energy consumption and CO2 emissions. The following conclusions were drawn:
In the analysis of a column-to-column connection using the strength design method, the maximum horizontal load of the connection was calculated to be 683.3 kN. Since a pre-cast composite column can be constructed irrespective of the connection method, a suitable connection scheme for the varying needs of each construction site can be selected. This in turn facilitates effective construction and reduces construction time.
The energy consumption of the pre-cast composite column calculated from the original unit of energy consumption was found to be 8920.22 MJ. Compared with those of the steel and SRC columns, the pre-cast composite column decreased the energy consumption by 70.26% and 44.33%, respectively.
The CO2 emissions of the pre-cast composite column calculated from the original unit of CO2 emission were found to be 843.96 kg-CO2. Compared with those of the steel and SRC columns, the pre-cast composite column decreased CO2 emissions by 71.96% and 43.22%, respectively.

The pre-cast composite column examined in this work can reduce energy consumption and CO2 emissions compared with those of steel and SRC columns. Thus, the application of the pre-cast composite column is an environmentally friendly solution that can reduce construction time.
